She describes the standard flow: receiving an invoice, checking for a PO number, logging into the system, forwarding to Purchasing for receipt confirmation, matching invoice to PO, sending to Manager for approval, and then scheduling payment. She mentions triggers: the managers approval is triggered after receipt confirmation and matching. Exceptions include missing PO (send back to supplier), discrepancies (email Purchasing), and unresolved issues (escalate to supervisor). Next, Dan (Purchasing Officer). His role starts when he receives the invoice from AP. He checks if invoice details match the PO. If off, he contacts supplier or tells AP to hold. If correct, he confirms back to AP. He emphasizes that without a PO, he cant proceed. He assumes AP moves it to Manager after his confirmation. So his step is confirmation after matching. Carlos (Department Manager). He gets notified after Purchasing confirms and matching is done. He approves if everything looks good, rejects or holds if suspicious. After approval, it goes back to AP for payment scheduling. So his step is final approval. Rita (AP Supervisor). Steps in during exceptions: when Mary cant match or Purchasing has unresolved issues. She contacts suppliers or coordinates. Handles invoices without POs by creating retrospective POs or rejecting. After resolving, the invoice returns to normal flow: Purchasing confirmation, Manager approval, then payment. Karen (Supplier Relationship Manager). Involved when discrepancies found, checks contracts, contacts suppliers to resolve issues. Doesnt handle approvals directly.
